bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R.H. Brooke, July 10, 1941

div1.p: Hench inquires if it would be possible to have the Sternberg correspondence copied or microfilmed, if it is not very extensive.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R.H. Brooke, July 10, 1941
div1.opener:
Copies to Mrs. Franck and Gen. Kean
Copy sent to Mr. Brooke, 8-21-41
July 10, 1941
Mr. R. H. Brooke, Chief Clerk
Office of the Surgeon General
War Department
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Brooke:
div1.p:
Will you kindly refer to my previous correspondence with you--
SCO 201 (Hench, P. S.)--letters of June 2 and June 17, 1941 and your
kind reply of June 11, 1941. It may be several months before I can
actually come to Washington to study the correspondence (letters and
telegrams) between the Surgeon General's office (especially that between
General Sternberg) and Walter Reed and his colleagues (Agramonte, Carroll
and Lazear) of the U. S. Army special Yellow Fever Board. I am delighted
to know that these data are available for my study. But I am wondering
whether I could make arrangements to study some of it in absentia. Could
you tell me about how much correspondence there is between General Stern-
berg and his office and the Army Yellow Fever Board in Havana (Camp Col-
umbia) between the dates August or September, 1900 and February, 1901?
If there are only a few dozen letters and telegrams would it be possible
for me to arrange to have them made available to an agent of mine who
could copy them for me? Recently, Mrs. Lillie W. Franck, 1237 Eighteenth
Street, N. E., Apt. 2, Washington, D. C. who I believe is or was working
in the Surgeon General's office and who is a friend of General Kean, helped
me with some stenographic work that General Kean and I were interested in.
I wondered whether these letters and telegraphic files noted above could
be made available to her to copy for me if they are not too extensive.
But if they are too numerous I will of course have to wait until I can
visit Washington myself.

Thank you very much for your further courtesy in this regard and
should you wish to make inquiries about me and my motives I am sure General
J. R. Kean or General Ireland would vouch for me.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
(over)
Mr. R. H. Brooke
- 2 -
July 10, 1941
P. S. Recently I had some data copied on microfilm by the
National Archives and also by the Surgeon General's library. Could the
material above mentioned be loaned to Mr. Hamer of the National Archives
or to the chief librarian of the Surgeon General's library that I might
get a microfilm made of it? If you think this possible, I shall be de-
lighted to pay for the expense of having the microfilm made. In that
way also a copy would be made available for the National Archives and
for the Surgeon General's library.
P.S.H.
